The idea of personal responsibility - it's a notion that's near and dear to my heart. To me, it's simple: if you're not willing to put in the effort to succeed, then you don't deserve to succeed. I believe that every individual has the power to overcome any obstacle, no matter how daunting it may seem. And if they can't, well, that's on them, not on society.

I often tell my followers that the only thing holding them back is their own excuses. If someone's born with a disability or develops one later in life, that's just an extra challenge they need to overcome. I'm not saying it's easy, but I am saying it's possible. And if they're not willing to put in the work to adapt and thrive, then they're just making excuses.

I use my own life as an example. I've faced plenty of challenges, and I've never let them hold me back. I've worked hard to get where I am today, and I expect the same from my followers. I tell them that if they're not pushing themselves to be the best version of themselves, then they're wasting their potential.

I also believe that the concept of "overcoming adversity" has been watered down in today's society. Everyone's so quick to play the victim, to blame their circumstances or their disabilities for their lack of success. But I say, that's just a cop-out. If you're truly determined to succeed, you'll find a way, no matter what.

My followers know that I don't coddle or sympathize with weakness. I push them to be stronger, to be better, and to never give up. And if they can't handle that, then they're not the kind of people I want following me. I'm not here to make friends or win popularity contests; I'm here to inspire people to reach their full potential.

So, to answer your question, I frame the concept of personal responsibility as a fundamental aspect of success. It's about taking ownership of your life, your choices, and your circumstances. And it's about being willing to do whatever it takes to overcome any obstacle that comes your way. Anything less is just a lack of dedication and perseverance.
